div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged beforehand. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gibraltar, Plymouth and London are Intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamer leaves Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m. on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fare is £22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
Passengers having paid fall fare in one direction are allowed an abatement of 25 per cent, on returning within 12 months.
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marseilles.
TO THE EAST.

The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Aden and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcutta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakin direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah, Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: IMPORTANT ANNOUNCEMENT
div.p: Steam Ploughing,Cultivating, Level ling and Grading. Mea6rs. J. & H. McLAREN, Manufacturers of Steam Ploughing Machinery, Midland Engine Works, Leeds, now beg to announce to the’r friends in Egypt, that Mr. Henry McLaren, one of their principal, will be in Egypt for the month of March, 1906. He will be glad to make appointments with any interested parties to show them oor steam plough tackle at work in Egypt, and will visit and inspect any lands on which it may be intended to work steam ploughs, and give most favourable prices for suitable Machinery.

He will aho show them our new Patient Gaeobeab, or veiling scoop, at work, which is thu most improved method of handling large quantities of sand or soil for levelling purposes which has yt t bten put upon the marktt.
L and Proprietor, Agriculturists, and Contractor*, are requested to communicate with Mr McLAREN at Bhepheard’s Hctil, Cai o, after March 1st, 1906.

PRESTINS- At Moharrem Bey, on the 30th inst., Alice Vivien Violettes, infant daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A.S. Preston, aged one day.
VACCARI.- At Alexandria, on the 30th March, Arbogasto Vaccari, in his sixty-second year.

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: The English Daily Newspaper, Established 1890.
Editor and Manager – – R. Smelling
Price: ONE PIASTRE TARIFF.
ABYSSINIA.

A special telegram which we published in our last issue announced that an agitation had arisen in Abyssinia on the death of Ras Makonnen, the presumptive successor to the Emperor Menelik. But there is no apparent reason why the Emperor should not continue for many years to come to rule the destinies of the Empire which he has done so much to consolidate and extend. There are few more interesting figures in Africa at this moment than the Emperor has succeded in welding the subordinate kinngdoms under his rule into a fairly homogenous State, and in obtaining the recognition of its independence by the European Powers who are its immediate neighbours. But time is required to give permanency to his work and the problem with which the Emperor Menelik is faced is all the more difficult because there is no direct heir to his throne and that the presumed successor has just died. In these circumstances it is perhaps inevitable that there should be intriguing among the ambitious Rases, some of whom, it is believed, have not been disinclined to coquette with the representatives of the European Powers at Adis Abeba. But so long as Abyssinia remains united no single European Power could conquer the country; while it would prove a difficult and costly buisness for Great Britian, France and Italy combined to overcome the resistance which the Abyssinians could offer. But the real difficulty in Abyssinia is Germany, for it is rumoured that Kaiser's Moracco policy is to be repeated in that quarter of the world. It is currently reported on the Continent that he purposses to enter a siplomatic protest against the treaty now being arranged between the Negus on the one part, and the British, French and Italian Governments on the other. This compact does not infringe in the slightest degree on any German interests in Abyssinia, shadowy as they are; traders of that nationally will be as free to carry on commercial buisness as those of the signatory Powers. The main purpose of the arrangement is to shut out foreign politicial intrigue by a self-denying ordance between the three European Powers which have secured a solid footing in Menelik's domininons. For a considerable time he has been patiently but firmly striving for that object, and the treaty represents the outcome of his statemanship. Practically, it amounts to the neutralisation of Abyssinia, both politically and commercially, the guarentors being the three Powers most closely concerned in its peaceful development. It is absurd, therefore, for Germany to question their right to come to an agreement which, so far from injuring whatever trading interests the Kaiser imagines to exist, must benefit them in common with those of all other foreign nations.

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL
div.p: German Despatch Boat.
The German despatch boat Loreloy left Alexandria this morning.
Standard Life Assurance Company.
The Hon. A. J. Davey has resigned his seat on the local board (if this ootnp&ny.
The Brindisi Mail.
The Brindisi mail will close at the G. P. O., Alexandria, at 3.10 p.m on Sunday.
Locusts.
A flight of locusts passed over Helouan on Wednesday, going from north to south.
St. Mark's, Alexandria.
The anthem tomorrow at the 6.15 p.m. service will he "O Saviour of the World,” by Goss.
Found Drowned.
The dead body of a native woman was found yesterday in the Mahmoudieh Canal, near Izbet Khorshid.
International Chamber of Commerce.
The annual general meeting of this Chamber will be held at the Grand Continental Hotel, Cairo, on Tuesday, April 10, at 5 p.m.
Coal Imports.
The imports of coal from January 1 to March 29 amounted to 290, 267 tons, as compared to 152,182 tons during the same period last year.
Fire in Harbour.
A fire broke last night in hold No. 3 of the Canard liner Veria, in Alexandria harbour. The extent of the damage is as yet unknown.
New Cairo Newspaper.
A new Turkish newspaper has made its appearance at Cairo, entitled "Togron Sony” (The Word of Truth). It is an organ of the Young Turkey Party.
Pearl Fisheries.
A credit of L.E. 6,000 has been opened by the Sudan Government fnr the purpose of safeguarding the pearl fisheries. A. special fishery department is to be formed.
Sunday Closing.
The shoemakers’ and drapers' establishments in Alexandria will be opened on the first and second Sundays of April, and will resume Sunday closing after Easter.
Penny Postage,
With effect from the 1st proximo, the postage on letters for St. Locia (Lesser Antilles) and St Vincent (B. W. I.) will be reduced and fixed at 5 millièmes for every 16 grammes or fraction thereof.
Egyptian Shells.

170 packages of Egyptian shells were offered for sale in London last week at the second shell sales of the year. 0f these 100 were sold at rather lower rates. Small to bold 3l to 12s 6d ; pickings 1/ 12s 6d to 2/ 3s ; pieces 2l 12s 6d to 2115s.
Egyptian Ivory.

Up to data eleven tons and seventeen hundredweight of Egyptian ivory has arrived in London for the quarterly sales which will be held on April 24. The total quantity arrived in London of ivory of all sorts, including Egyptian, is twenty eight tons.
"The Sphinx.”

We are asked to inform our readers that the last .number of the “Sphinx" for the present season will appear Tuesday next with a special illustrated supplement containing full accounts of the visit of their Royal Highnesses the Prince and Princess of Wales to Cairo.
Municipal Library.

The Municipal Library at Alexandria will be reopened to the public as from Monday next on the days and at the same hours as hitherto, viz., on Mondays, Tuesdays Wednesdays,Thursdays, and Saturdays from 9 a.m. to noon and from 4 to 7 p.m. On Fridays, Sundays, and holidays, it will be open from 10 a.m. to noon.
Army of Occupation.

As will have been noticed in our Army and Navy column yesterday, the Army Estimates fihow that provision has been made for the maintenance of 4,008 British troops in Egypt and Crete in the coming year, at a total cost of £312,770. The British troops last year, exclusive of the detachments in Crete, numbered 3 243.
Church of Scotland.

The Sacrament of the Lord’s Sopper will be celebrated in St. Andrew's Church, Alexandria, at the close of divine service tomorrow morning. Visitors and friends cordially invited. Mr. Los. E Dutton's large and beautiful model of the Tabernacle of Israel will be exhibited in the church tomorrow evening at 6 o’olook. The explanation will be given by Mr. Float.
The St. James's.

All the man; patrnns of Shepheard's Hotel will be sorry that Mr. Richard Marbury is leaving the staff of the establishment. Mr. Marbury has taken the St. Jamea's Restaurant and on Monday next will inaugurate his acquisition of the property. We wish him every success in his new undertaking, for it would be difficult to find a more experienced and genial proprietor to preside over the well known Cairo restaurant.

div.head: OUR SPECIAL CABLES.
div.p: IMPERIAL PARLIAMENT.
PREMIER CUTS UNHEROIC FIGURE.
(Gazette's Special Service.)
London, Saturday.

The Press considers that the Premier cut an unheroic figure in the House of Commons yesterday in making an anject surrender to the Labour Party over the Trades Disputes Bill. This is not only discreditable to his statesman ship but, what is more important, it threatens to be a danger to the State.
Mr. Wyndhsm’s scathing criticism of the Government marks a new era in his career.
COUNT WITTE’S RETIREMENT.
(Gazette's Special Service).
London, Friday.
The influential papers of St. Petersburg publish reports of the impending resignation of Count Witte owing to ill-health, necessitating his retirement from public affairs.

div.head: THE PRINCES' LAWSUIT
div.p: Maitre Manneardi, of Cairo, is leaving for Italy on Thursday next in order to, discuss the bearings of the Khédivial Princes' ease with the Hon. Tommaso Vella, late Warden of the Seals and President of the Italian Chamber of Deputies, who has been briefed by the heirs of the Khedive Ismail.

div.head: UNIVERSITY OF ALEXANDRIA
div.p: Sheikh Mohamed Shaher, president of the Board of Ulema of Alexandria, informed a representative ot the "Gazette” in the course of an interview yesterday that the schenfe to found a religions university at Alexandria only took definite shape two months ago, although it had for some time past been a favourite project of his. The site most suitable tor the university is at Qabbari, near the Tekieh, now occupied by eshesbes erected by the Municipality, which has given the land to the Ulema Board.

The Khedive is much interested in the scheme, and it has also been favourably received by the Financial Adviser. The project will be submitted to the Council of Ministers. The name for the university will be chosen by the Khedive.

div.head: THE ULEMA STRIKE
div.p: The strike of the Ulema teachers of Alexandria still continues. They demand an increase of pay and have appealed to the Khedive and A1 Azhar No decision has been arrived at as to what is to be done in regard to satisfying their demands.

div.head: FRENCH POSTAL RATE TO EGYPT.
div.p: Picture postcards bearing written communications on the address Bide, in the part reserved for this purpose, are now by the French Government admitted to the ten-centimes rate for traffic with the French post-offices abroad, and also with Egypt, Haiti, and the Transvaal.

div.head: MALTEASE BENEVOLENT SOCIETY.
div.p: At the general meeting Of the members of this society the balance-sheet for last year was submitted and approved. Excellent work has been done by the committee in aid of the less fortunate class of their community. 49 persons were admitted to hospital and the sooiety paid for 1,281 days’ treatment, besides 778 medical visits during the year, with 22 operations. The committee districted 6.441 loaves and provided 925 persons with free medicine. House rent for 58 months was paid for those of their compatriots who wére in a very indigent condition and free passage home provided to the incurable. The society also contributed towards the upkeep of the Maltese Viotoria School, a free school founded by ihe Maltese community in commemoration of Queen Viotoria a Diamond Jubilee.

The committee for the ensuing year was elected as follows :—Mr. Leandro Camilleri, president ; Mr. Roberto Stabile, vice-president ; Mr. A. Cilia, treasurer ; Mr. A. Caruana Nani, secretary ; Mr. G. Podesta, accountant ; Mr. C. Aquilina and Mr. Alberto Cumbo, auditors ; and Messers A. Eajada, C. Buhagiar Borg. A. They, and G. Morello, members.
Mr. Mario Voila, who has been president of the society for five yeats, did not offer himself for re-election.

div.head: THE ROYAL VISIT.
div.p: PRINCE PRESENTS COLOURS TO THE INNISKILLINGS.
A PLEASANT CEREMONY.

The barrack square at Kasr el Nil pre aented a very animated see e yesterday afternoon on the oooasion of the presentation of new colours to the 2nd Royal InniskilliDg Fusiliers by H.R.H. the Priooe of Wales. The bandstand had been decorated with bunting for the occasion and the'galleries around the square were foil of spectators. Special invitations had been issned to the following gnests by Col. Cox, command:ng the 2nd Battalion of the distingui-hçd Irish regiment whioh received so signal an honour from the Heir Apparent : the Earl and Chnntess of Cromer, the Earl and Countess of Shaftesbnry, Mr. Frank and Lady Eva Dngdale, Lt.-Col. Sir Arthnr Bigge, Commander Sir Charles Cost, the Hon. Derek Keppel and M'g. Keppel, Commander Godfrey Fansaett, Mr. H. Montgomery, the 8irdar and Lady Wingate,* Misa Danford, General, Mrs. and Miss Bollock, Major Hoskins, Major and Mrs. Knight. Capt and Mrs. Bailey, Major Peroy-Smith, Lt.-Col. and Mrs. Mantel!, Lt.-Col. and Mrs. Ludlow, Col. Magil), the Rev. B. J. and Mrs. Hardy, the Rev. E. Ryan, the Rev. W. 8. and Mrs. Jaffray, Lt. Col. and Mrs. Atkinson, Lt.-Col. and Mrs. Duckett, Major Lawson, Major Pine- Coffin, Major and Mrs. Cave, Lt-Col. and Mrs. Markham, Major and Mrs. Oxley, Miss Gardiner, Lt-Col. Watson Pacha, Capt and Mrs. Qilleon, Miss Ferrard, Major and Mrs. Parsons, Co).and Mrs. Bird, Major and Mrs. Staok, Lient. R J. Collins, Lt.-Col. and Mrs. Bernard, Lt-Col. and Mrs. Matchett, the Commodore and officers of H.M.S. Renown, the Captain and officers of H.M.S. Minerva, Mr. and Mrs. Alban, Hon. Mr. and Mrs. Iddings, Miss Iddings, Co), and Mrs. MoCraoken, Mansfield Paoha, Mr. and Mrs. Rnmbold, Captand Mrs. Maclean, Mr. and Mrs. M. de C. Findlay. Lt-Col. and Mrs, Cox, Major and Mrs. Wilding, Capt and Mrs. Somerville, the oolonel and officers 1st K. R. Rifles, the colonel and officers 1st Royal Dnblm Fusiliers, the AHjutant- Qeneral-and officers Egyptian Army, Col. Todd, Major and Mrs. Mylrea, Cept. and Mrs. Duffus, Major and Mrs. Donegan, Rev. F. and Mrs. Anderson, Rev. Sydney and Mrs. Smith, Sir Walter Lawrence, and the Lady Mary Criohton.

On the arrival of the Prinoe and Prinoesa of Wales at 4.40 p.m, the oeremonial began After the battalion, which was formed in line facing the stand, had saluted the arrival of the Prinoe and Princeu, the old oolours, borne hy Lieutenants Ball and Loftus, were carried round the battalion to the strains of "Auld Lang Syne." Then c&me the presentation oeremony. The battalion firmed three aides of a square, the new oolours in their oases laid upon the drums, and the Rev. E Hardy, Senior Chaplain to the Forces in Egypt, read the servies.

The hymn “Brightly gleams our banner” was sung and the Lord’s Prayer repeated aloud. The Prinoe and Prinoess, who had descended from the stand with Lord Cromer, the Sirdar and Lady Wingate, Watson Paoha. Mr. M. de C. Findlay and the officer commanding, stood facing the band. Thu colours were then unrolled and handed by the Prince of Wales to Lieate nants Jennings and Adams, who reoeived them on bended kree.
At the conolnsion of this part of the oere- mony H.R.H. the Prince of Wales addressed the regiment as follows :—

"Colonel Cox, officers, non-commissioned officers, and men of the 2nd Battalion Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers,-—I am very pleased to prêt eut these new colours to you here today, on my way borne from India. It was in that country that your battalion was first raised in 1858* where it saw most of its active service. These colours bear the nsmes of the campaigns and battles iu which the regiment has taken part. They are rightly venerated as the emblem of the gallant deeds of thosu who • erved and of those who have died for their country. I feel sure that the colours will te an incentive to all ranks to maintain the great traditions of the regiment and to add fresh honours to its records. In handing the oolours to you 1 am confident that they will be safe in your keeping.”
To these kind wordsColonelCox replied:—

Yoor Royal Highness,— I only regret that a. very considerable part of the battalion I oommand is absent in Crete and Cyprus on dnty and is therefore, unfortunately, unable to hear yonr most gracious words. In their name, and in the name of the offioers and men of the battalion here pre lent, and, I may add, in the name ol the four Irish oonnties that form onr territorial district, I thaï k yonr Royal Highness most sinoerely for the great honour yon have done us this day, and for the gracious terms in which you have expressed your appreciation of the past services pf the regiment. I can assure your Royal Highness that every offioer and man “who is fortanate enough in the future to serve under these new oolours just consecrated to the servioe of our Sovereign and ouroonntry, will nse his utmost endeavours to maintain the good name which the lnnis- ki.ling Begiment has always borne, whether in peace or war,and thus oarry on onr glorious traditions of the past.

The 2nd R. Inniskilfing Fusillon were formerly one of thé E. India Company’s European regiments and saw sorvice and won renown in every Indian campaign. Wlion in 1858 tho old company regime passed away the regiment was incorporated in the British Army and has added to its reputation in India and S. Africa.

On the close of the Colonel’s speech the battalion formed into line and the new colours were carried round to the tune of the "British Grenadiers." The general salute to the colours and the Royal salats followed, and before the close of this ceremony his Royal Highness inspected the battalion, afterwards expressing himself highly pleased with its appearance. The following offioers of the battalion then had the honour of being presented to bis Royal Highness by Col. Cox : –Major C. A. Wilding, Capt. Somerville, Capt. Evans (Adjt.), Capt Blachett, Capt. Mathers, and Lieutenants Adams, Jennings, Ball, Loftus, Doffiu, and Lient, and Qr. Master McDonnell. Mrs. Cox Mrs. Wilding, Mrs. Somerville, and Mrs. McDonnell also bad the honour of being presented to H.R.H. the Princess ofWales.

div.head: THE SUCRERIES.
div.p: At the Mixed Tribunals, Cairo, this morning, Maitre Carton de Wiart stated that all the creditors bad approved of the following appointments, and which after due consideration the Court decided to confirm :—

Maitre Horftbitns was appointed as syndio, also M. Roux de Vance, manager of the Hawamdish factory. These gentlemen are to act together with Prot. Sampaolo, who has already been appointed by the Conrt,and under the supervision of Huari Paoha. Mr. Mo- Langhlin. manager of the Ottoman Bank at Cairo and M. Millet, delegate of the Banque d'Union Parisienne.

Discussing the absence of business on the Paris Bourse, the correspondent of a London financial contemporary remarks : The only fluctuation, for which a good reason exists, is that of the shares of the Egyptian Sngar Refineries. They are now worth about 8f. or 9f., if a buyer can he found, Since the Court of Appeal has cot firmed the bankrupcy ordered a fortnight ago by the Tribnruri of Commerce. The interested groups, shareholders' and banks holding Cronier bills, will now endeavour to induce tha Official Receiver to accept the concordat; which the coarts have rejected. On the other band, it is becoming more and more certain (a report which I mentioned weeks ago) that Sir Ernest Cassel and his friends will refloat the unfortunate concern, around which so many Egyptian, in addition to French and English, interests are centred.

div.head: SOLDIERS AND SAILORS' FAEILIES ASSOCIATION.
div.p: At a committee meeting of the above association it was decided to raise a fund to provide a district nurse for the Alexandrian locality, to attend such cases of illness in the soldiers and sailors’ families ss are unsuitable for treatment in hospital. The subscriptions received in 1905, which may be taken as an average year, amounted tu £22.0-7 ½ d. It the present scheme is carried into effeot it will necessitate an extra annual expenditure of £100 or £120. Thus in order to maintain a nurse and carry on the ordinary relief-work of the association, a yearly income of nearly £160 will be required. It is proposed to apply to the head office of the Association in London for an annnal monetary grant, and to raise the remainder of the sum looally. For this purpose subscriptions or donations will be thankfnlly received. Cheques may be made payable to the Hon. Treasurer, Alexandria Branob, S.S. F.A., and all communications rhould be sent to him addressed British Headquarters, Alexandria.

div.head: PORT SAID NOTES.
div.p: ROUGH WEATHER IN CANAL.
ALL SHIPS OBLIGED TO TIE UP.
(From our Correspondent).
Port Said, Thursday.

Last night Port Said streets were quite deserted. All day it had been exceptionally hot and damp ; in fact, it was by far the worst day we have had this year. In the evening the wind sprang up and long before midnight it was blowing a gale. All the ships in the Casai, 17 in number, were obliged to tie up, being unable to proceed. Bad weather is also reported from outside, several Ships being overdue. There has been a steady wind blowing all day, and early this evening it started to rain heavily, with the result that the whole town ia nearly under water. It is a wonder that some steps are not taken to put things In a somewhat more satisfactory state, as the present system of drainage, if there is any, is a disgrace to the town.
TRAFFIC STOPPED IN CANAL.

The S.S. Mandalay went ashore in the Canal last night. She had several passengers on board. Togs were at once Sent to her assistance but ware unable to get her off, and on their return to Port Said it was found necessary to send more tags with fighters down, and they started to discharge the cargo immediately. Finally she was refloated at midnight after having discharged most of her cargo. Traffic has been stopped all day.
THE DUKE OF CONNAUGHT.

The D. O. A. Prinzregent entered the Canal (Suez and) at midday to day with the Duke and Duchess of Connaught on beard, and had to tie up owning to the Mandalay being ashore. The Priozregent will not make a long stay at Port Said, and the Duke will probably not come ashore here.
LAST OF THE CHATHAM.

This afternoon the Canal Company blew up the remainder of the old S.S. Chatham. They bad been prepared for this final explosion for some time, and had been waiting for a favourable ohanoe, whioh arrived this afternoon when traffio was stopped through the Mandalay being ashore. The explosion has been satisfactory, and the only reminder of the fatal spot where the Chatham went ashore is the large hole in the Canal bank.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA TRAMWAY CO.
div.p: The Ministry of the Interior has under consideration a scheme for the employment of motor omnibuses in Alexandria an its suburbs in connection with the tramway system of the Alexandria Tramway Company. The Alexandria Municipality has alresdy informed the Tramway Company that it has no objection to the employment of motor omnibuses by the company.

The company, on receipt of the Ministry's approbation, will start motor omnibases with seating accommodation for twenty persons in each ’bus. The ’buses will be fitted with first and second-class accommidation end will run in connection with the company’s network of tramways, thus affording an easy and rapid system of intercommunication with all parts of the city.

div.head: WHEAT IN THE SUDAN
div.p: Several Egyptian landowners who visited the Sudan this winter are of opinion, says the “Sudan Times," that the country is admirably saited for wheat growing. lt is maintained by one of them that the net profit on the yield of a feddan cannot fall below P.T. 200. This he says may be less than the profit realized from cotton, but it should be borne in mind that so long as the labour in the Sudan are limited only small a be placed nnder cotton cultivation. It is easier to teach the natives to grow wheat than cotton; besides, the first does not require so many hands as the latter. The yield per feddan of wheat shonld average five ardebs.

div.p: (Avjiurd'hui A midi et demie)

Avec l’InvestmeDt, on a échangé beaucoup d'Agrioole, de Cassa di Scouto, de Delta Laud et de Trust. Ces derniers ont snbi nne réaotion par suite de ventes assez importantes de la spéculation.

Les prévisions pour la semaine prochaine sont excellentes. En dépit des fêtes de Pâques qui détourneront un peu da marohé l’attention pubfique, on s'attend à une forte acosntoation de la hausse sur les valeurs solides, pour peu que les marchés européens encouragent ce mouvement.
Lord Curzon is staying at the Savoy Hotel, Cairo.
The Earl and Countess of Meath are staying at Mena Honse Hotel.
Sir William and Lady Ewart, Misses Ewart, Mr. Ewart, and party bave returned from Upper Egypt and taken up their residence at Mena House Hotel.

A dinner was given by Rear-Admiral Sigsbee on board the oruiser Brooklyn yesterday evening, being one of a series given in return for the hospitality he and the offioers of the squadron have reoeived ashore. Among the guests were Rear-Admiral Sir Massie and Lady Blom- field, Mr. and Mrs. James Hewat, Judge and Miss Batchellor, Mr., Mrs. and Miss Peel, M. and Mme Girard, Mrs. Reiss, etc.

Among the passengers who left Alexandria yesterday by the Messageries Maritimes S.S. Portugal were Count and Connteas de Vanreal, Earon van Tbielman, Mrs. Carton de Wiart, Mrs. Hunter, Co, and Mrs.Cadreu, Mr. Edgar Soares, M. Hocb, Miss Sheppard, Col. Pitzherbert, Mr. and Mrs. WorthingtoD, Capt. Carey, etc.
Among the passengers who left for Constantinople by the Khédivial S.S. Ismailia were Connt and Conntesa Sierstorptf, Baroness Lan Mainchboffer and daughter, Mohsen Bey Fauzi, and M. Le Bargy.

Mr. Antonio de Beuednooi. Consol at Alexandria for the United States of’Mexloo, who has been seriously ill with gastrio fever, has left for Greece by the Russian steamer accompanied by his family and a physician. It is hoped that the change will restore Mr. Beneducci to his usual health.

Captain F.G. Poole. D.S.O., East Yorkshire Regiment, now serving with the Bgyptian Army, and who has just been promoted to his captaincy in the gallant Snappen, has had a varied career. A Kent man by birth, his fad has been foreign travel and he has seen a lot ol the world. He was gazetted to the East Yorks, from Sandhurst, in 1892, and from 1806 to 1698 he wae employed in the British Central Africa Protectorate, and shared in tha expeditions against Chilwa and Mpezeui (medal with clasp), saw further servioe io the troubles in North Rhodesia and was in China daring the Boxer troubles. During that very trying period he was iu the besieged Legations of Peking and commanded the volunteers of all nationalities whioh helped to hold the place. He was wounded during the defence of the Legations, and afterwards was a Staff Officer of the China Field Force, and combined the daties of Transport Officer with th it of interpreter, he being a very able Chinese soholar (mentioned in despatches, D. S O., medal with clasp). Captain Poole, who for the past three years has bean attached to the Khedive’s army, has written a bit on foreign travel, and hs has the honour of being a Fellow of the Royal Geographical Sooiety.

We regret to annonnos the death, which took place yesterday from heart disease, of Mr. Arbogasto Vaccari. for twelve years iospector of the Alexandria branch of ths S.P.C.A. Deceased was formerly in the Coast Guard Administration, where he held the rank of Saghcolaghassi. div.head: THE NATAL CRISIS.
div.p: DAMAGING THE WHITE MAN'S PRESTIGE.
LORD ELGIN GIVES EXPLANATION.
London, March 30.

Lord Elgin and Mr. Winetm Chnrohill, questioned in Pail-ament, declared that they had to information regarding the resignation of the Natal Mioiatry beyond a press telegram. They j ns tided the suspension of the executions in view of a possible demand for the assistance of British troops to repress a native rising. (R.)
Durban, March 30.

The general opinion in Natal is that the present Ministry which has resigned cannot be replaced, and that the interference of the Imperial Government is considered as gravely damaging to the prestige of the white man. The 12 natives were tried by courtmartial lasting eight days. (Reuter)
London. March 30.

House of Lords —Lord Elgin read adespatch - 'from the Governor of Natal, to which he replied that in the light of the information famished, he recognised that the decision in this grave matter rested with Natal.

The Governor’s despatch detailed the circumstances of the court martial and the Ministry’s resignation. It concluded with the hope that his Lordship weald now withdraw the suspension of the execution, which is excitiog intense feeling.

Lord Elgin’s reply stated that he never intended to interfere with the ac tion of the responsible Government, bnt in view of the presence of British troops in the Colony, he is bonnd to obtain fall information on each matters and regretted that the Governor did not supply details earlier. (Reuter)

div.head: BURIED FOR TWENTY DAYS.
div.p: SURVIVORS OF COURRIERES DISASTER.
Lens, March 30.
Fourteen of the Cûurrières miners were reeoned alive and well, having lived on scraps of food and oats. (Reuter)
Lens, March 30.
Thirteen survivors of the Coorrières catastrophe were recovered in the morning. They had lived for twenty days on putrid oats, meat, and water. (Havas)

div.head: RUSSIAN JEWISH MASSACRES.
div.p: AUTHORS ACQUITTED.

St. Petersburg, March 30. The Senate has acquitted Prefect Neidhardt and the Governor of Karloff, the reputed authors of the Jewish massacres at Odessa. It is believed that the decision is due to the personal order of the Tsar. (Reuter)

div.head: STOPPING RUSSIAN PILGRIMAGES.
div.p: Sevastopol, March 30.
The bodies of Lieutenant Schmidt and of the other sailors executed have been exhumed, taken out to sea, and sank in order to pat a stop to pilgrimages. (Reuter)

div.head: COUNT BULOW'S RESIGNATION.
div.p: Berlin, March 30.
The rumours of the resignation of Count von Below are semi-offioially denied. (Reuter)

div.head: AMERICAN INSURANCE BILL
div.p: New York, March 30.
The House has unanimonsly passed the Insarance Bill regarding the New York and Mutual Life Insurance Companies. (Reuter)

div.head: COAL STRIKE IN AMERICA.
div.p: New York, March 30.
A simultaneous strike in the bituminous and anthracite coalfields has been ordered for the 2nd April. It will affect 410,000 persons. (Reuter)

div.head: THE STRANDING OF THE SULLY.
div.p: Toulon, March 30.
The Naval Court has acquitted Captain Guiberteau, who stranded the Sally. (Haw)

div.head: HOME RACING.
div.p: London, March 30.
Grand National Steeplechase. (Liverpool), 1 Ascetic Silver ; 2. Red Lad ; 3. Aunt May.
23 ran. Won by 10 lengths. Two lengths dividing 2nd and 3rd. Batting. 20 to 1 Ascetic Silver ; 33 to 1 Red Lad ; 25 to 1 Annt May.
(Reuter)

div.head: SPIRIT OF COMMERCIALISM.
div.p: LIFE OF OLD SERIA DYING OUT.
(From our Correspondent)
Beyrout, March 20.

One would think hat a town like Beyrout, with its fairly large population, its important steamship commumation, and the foot of its being a terminus several railway lines, that keep it in touch win the outside world, would , afford a not altoether sterile object for a newspaper correspodent. But there are many factors that conspire against public life manifesting itself here a brilliant functions, fêtes, and interesting eents. Lack of security has at one time determied an exodus of the wealthy class, that is the rainspring of any such manifestations of a public or semi public nature ; and Egypt has ben at the same time the rival and the gainer nereby. Then Byrout is in a transition perid. The Oriental’s insouciance and his natural addiction to pleasure are being beaten out by the invading and conquering spirit of commercialism, that is the dominant force of moden times. Formerly, and not very far back, it res not uncommon to meet people in the street roaming aimlessly about, and wafting thei careless souls in music on the moonlit air. The sound of the Oud, accompanying the legoid notes of Oriental song, used to fill the stillness of the night with melody in every quarêr of the town. The life, however, of old Syri is dying out, and the new spirit is graspingly bent on gain. In other countries where thaiway of commercialism is supreme, prosperity supplants the spontaneous expression of tlis poetry of the soul, and the flow of gold thows a mantle of brilliancy on public life, and,with its patronage of art, gives this brilliancy the higher magic touch.
Dull Monotony of Life.

Unfotunately political restrictions in this countrymilitate against the growth of such boundless prosperity on the crest of which Egypt row stands, thanks to the wise administration with which it is blessed. Thus it is that lie with us ber passes on with dull monotny, so much so that the events of a whole season may be chronicled within the limited space of a letter.

Our Governor-General, thanks to that European art of his career, has cultivated the taste for social entertainments. The perfect organsation of the ball that he has, last summer, given in honour of Admiral Danville, in the gracious garden adjoining his residence, testied to the cultivation of such taste on artisdo and systematic lines. The garden looked like a fairy field with trees laden with fruit of multicolored lights. The music and the buffet were worthy of the decorations and the general fit-up.
Breaking with Tradition.

This winter his Excellency gave a series of dinners to the Consols, inviting two at a time, and the cordiality of the receptions was sum that he once trod a measure with the eltferly but vivaoions mother of one of the Consub. This, of course. gave oocasion for severe omnmsnt on the part of the fanatioal olasa of Mrslsms. But just as the Turk has been so far broken into European lift that he has now a scruples in serving liquors at weddings and other festive occasions, so will car Moslem Arsbs break, with tims, into the antiquated and primitive shell that tradition has, so far, to well defended against the attacks and the changes of time. It may, however, take ages cefore a complete regeneration is effected, especially if existing political conditions one- time to obtain. The Vali gave lately a charity ball which was largely attended and was bound to be of a very medley character as the tickets were distributed broadcast. Some of the exclusive set took a sort of hanghty office at such plebian promiscuity. A French young lady rather emancipated and bold mystified the crowd by appearing at one of the windows in the gallery of the hall dressed as aTarkish lady with the diaphanous yasmak throwing an ethereal charm aifrqnd her eyes. Had she been too careful about concealing her identity she might hive thrown some compromising suspicions on the Valia harem.
American Squadron's Visit.

The appearance in our waters of the United States squadron created a stir. The squadron consisted of the cruisers Brooklyn, Galveston and Chattanooga.,The former had visited our Yort on the occasion of the troubles between Christian and Moslems that took such a serious turn and culminated in the transfer of the Uta Vali, Rachid Bey, now Pacha. Her reappearance therefore gave the pleasure that is felt on seeing again a familiar and friendly face. The Brooklyn belongs already to the immortal class of veteran fighters. In the officers’ mess room one sees a most onrions and interesting relic. It is a framed fragment of one of the armoured plates of the valiant ship that was rent by a dead above the water line from the Spanish man-of-war Christobal Colon during the engagement off Santiago de Cuba on July 3, 1898. In the centre of the hole stands the picture of the unfortunate Chriatobal-Colon, which was subsequently sunk by her Yankee adversary. A proud relic this Darfing the few days of their stay the conducted the crew ashore was almost exemplary and this rebounds with credit on the U. S. navy discipline.

Mr Bergholz, the American Consul-General, gave a dancing evening reception to Rear Admiral Sigsbee and his staff on the 8th March. As the reception happened to fall in Lent many of the invited, specially amongst native Catholics and Orthodox, could not attend through scruples of religions observance although the Consular Body was in full attendance.
Saving the Consul's Face.

But it was the American Colony that saved the Consul's face. Missionaries though they most all are, none failed to attend. The patriatic sense triumphed over puritanic simples. Indeed many of the Syrian Protestant College staff joined in the dances with a rest. The function was altogether a successful one. It was a moonlight night and the air was balmy and soft. But the chief cause of its success was the generous and oordial hospitality of the ho-t and i hostess, the Consnl General’s step-in her. There was an absence of restrain that was characteristically American and which indeed constitutes the supreme charm of entertainments of this kind.

Rear-Admiral Sigsbee visited more than once the Syrian Protestant College and ad dressed a gathering of students. On the last day before the squadron’s departure for Alexandria he invited all the students of the different departments to the flagship.

Dr. Howard Bliss, president of the College, knew President Roosevelt in college and on the occasion of his recent visit to the United States he bad an audience of the President, who evinced a lively interest in the good work of the college. Dr. Howard Bliss is a triple impersonation of the spirit of the diplomatist, orator, and scholar, and with these qualities and physical endowments he wins the sympathies of all those with whom becomes in control. The college over which he presides is a powerful moral element in the East which he is well qualified to wield and control.
Public Amusments.

So much for the social side. As regards amusements of a purely public character, we find the censorship of the Press unfortnnately a relentless enemy to every movement in favour of dramatic art. Despite the enconragement of the French Consulate a fairly decent troupe that contemplated paying a visit to our town eventually gave up the idea Besides the forbidding attitude of the cemor there is a lack of generous patronage on the part of the public. Prim decorum on the one hand and want of appreciation on the other, together with the risks of venturing out of doors at night end the repulsive condition of the roads, all these are obstaces to the enterprise of theatrical companies. So the sole resources of the refied and cultured is books and nature; and an occasional chat with persons of congenial taste.

Sporting movenents have Badly failed. The Race Club that bad made such a promising debut has quickly collapted and the race grounds are now abandoned and advertised for sale as a bankrupt concern. Here gain the Government has the largest share of criminal

div.head: REVUE COMMERCIALE
div.p: Coton

Malgré le oalme qni a dominé pendent la matinée de Samedi, le tenue du marché» été relativement soutenue et même en olfiture une petite reprise de 1/16 sur les cours de la veille e été enregistrée, mais la journée de Lundi et particulièrement la première séance de Mardi ont été lourdes et le Mai a fini par tomber à 30 1/8. A ce point la tendance paraissait absolument mauvaise, quand tout d’un coup les offres de ventes ayant oessé, les haussiers ont pu réagir et la journée s’est définitivement terminée sur la oote de 20 7/89. Ajoutons enoore que Liverpool aveo ses meilleures dispositions pour nos cotons, sons forme de ventes pins copieuses, a constitr é pour la spéculation un ES;ond encouragement.
Le lendemain, l'Amérique avec s» hausse de 10 points pour le matinée, et Liverpool avec ses 1,50«- Balles de ventes en Egyptiens, pour la soirée, ont servi non seulement à consolider les cours, mais enoore à les taire avancer jusqu’à 20 17/82. ,
Hier, c’est ce même prix qui a été sffiohé au tableau à 6 heures dn soir ; toutefois, dans l’intervalle nous avions momentanément réact'onné à 20 13/82 et oela sons la pression de que'qnes réalisations. Anjonrd'hni, finalement, quoique l'Amérique nous Boit venue extraordinsire- ment faible, d'est la ferme'é qui a régné et les deux cotes dqja journée noua présentent une oouveils hans-e graduelle de 7/32 de tallari, oe qui a porté le j Mai à 20 3/4 comme dernier oours.
Tout téermé, c’est dono 1/2 tallari de gagné sur Vendredi passé, et, dans ces conditions, le parti de la hausse n'a pas perdu son temps. La tendance,, pour le moment, semble encore bonus, mais quant à taire des pronostios poor la sqjje, cela devient fine question difficile et même Impossible aveo on marché spéoo- latif et aussi nerveux que celui que nous avons depuis qnelque temps ; il n’en est pas moins vrai cependant que les idées d’une baisse marquée perdent chaque jonr du terrain: noua pourrons avoir des réactions, mais none n irons jsmais loin dans la voie de la baisse et à chaque mouvement de oette nature il «accédera sûrement et sans trop tarder nne tentative pour faire hausser de nouveau les coure II ne sert à rien d’ergoter, oar la position statistique de l’artiole est absolument eu faveur des détenteurs des contrats et ne pent aller qn’on s’améliorant dans ce sens aveo la.
La nouvelle recolte a continue a avoir une tenne stable et a attirer l'attention de la speculation; et en definitive le Novembre a gagne 3/16 de tallari au cours de 16 ½. On pretend même qne l’exportation s’y est in’éressér: o’est possible, mais ce'a ne rent être que or des quantités réduites et en converture de ven'sr à la consommation poor embarquement Octobre et non pour des dates plus éloignées, car, d'après les renseignements qu’on a bien vonln nous crmmnniquer, aveo preuves à l’appui, la filaturo n’a l'a:r de vouloir se soumettre à nos exigences que ponr ce qui concerne U vieil'ç récolte et, les tout premiers besoins de la pro/ ohaine campagne. Pour plus tard, oe seront les circonstances qui devront régler sa ligne de oondnite.
Quoique l’activité c'ait été qu’in'ermittente, le disponible a donné lieu.à des affaires plus importantes qne oela n’a été le cas depnis deux semaines ; msis, ponr ce qui est des prix, pour cette fois, la oote officielle ne nous présente ancon obaDgement sur la semaine précédenteLes exportations ont dépassé les prévisions et leur total a fiui par atteindre le chiffre de balles, contre 12.800 poor la cemaine correspondante en i?05. Il est vrai qne l’on dit qu’à la suite de l’angmentatiou prévue do tarif d’exportation ponr Avril quelqnes embarquements ont été anticii és.maiB oela n’empêohe pas qu'en attendant la marchandise part et qr6 poor la semaine prochaine on prévoit aussi des expéditions areea importantes. L’année dernière, la première asmcvne d'Avril s é‘é de balles, et la deuxième de 21.000 balles. Les arrivages de leur côté ont é‘é, pour Muaidire, misérables, soit 40.0C0 cantare, contre l’année passée et, qn’on le veuille ou noD, ce fait ne peut être considéré que oomme une confirmation des informations que les existences à l’intérieur sont près de leur épni sement final.
Quant au stock, il est tombé à 1.309.000 oantars, soit oantars 241.000 an-dessous de l’année dernière à la même date, ce qai fait qne nos ressources visibles et invisibles pour le restant de la oampagne ne sont plus que de cantar 1.500.000 environ, centre cantars 2.400.000.
Liverpool a été nn peu pins actif pour l’Egyptien disponible et le conrs s’en est res senti sons la forme d’une avanoe de 3/16 pour le fully good fair. Quelqnes dépêohes du dit marché semblent faire oroire que les ventes assez rondes de cette semaine ne sont pas poor la filature, mais bien en grande partie poor le déconvert qui cherche à se mettre de la marchandise en main poor sa défense ultérieure. Since c’est pas du coton qui s’écoule par la filature, o’est da ooton qni restera immobilisé pendant assez longtemps et au fond oe sera autant de balles qui ne pèseront plus sur le marché juequ'à la date de leor remise en Vente, c’est-à-dire en Mai au pins tût. Seole- ' à la boat dans la réception du mai et ne déser pèrent pas de faire payer des prix fabuleux pour tout ce qui ne pourra pas lenr être livré. Ces menaoes, qui, comme nont le dion dans notry dernière rê Tuf, n'avaient produit joequ’io que l’effet d’autant de coops de bê'on dans l’eau, sembleraient dono être au oontraire autant de oonps de massue qui pendent sur la tête des imprudents de Liverpool qui se sont engagés si à la légère, eu perdant toot à fait de vne la situation de notre marché et toute possibilité de seoonrs de notre part. Aveo denx ou trois tallaris de difiérenoe de prix on ne voit pas bien qnel est oelui qai s’amuserait à envoyer dn coton à la venta en Angleterre. Les circonstances peuvent certes modifier les meilleurs plans, mais ilulen est pas moins vrai que pour le moment las aobetenrs de contrats de ooton égyptien à Liverpool ont tontes les obanosa pour enx, à rendition qne leurs quantités soient suffisantes pour produira l'égorgement visé.
Les fntnrs ontgagné 16/64 dans la semaine, Serait ce là une oonséqoenoe des raohats qne tente de faire le déoonvert 1
Sanf une journée, le reste du temps les ventes en Américain disponible à Liverpool sont restées dans la note modérée et, oomme prix. à 3 points près, les choses n’ont pas changé. Pour le livrable il en a été presque dè mê o,
Le prand mouvement que l’on annonçait d'Amérique et qui devait porter le ooton à 12 oents au moirsn’apas continné etl'on prétend même que Price est en train da vendre ; seulement on affirme, d'antres souroes, que 1a réaotion provoquée par les offres dn olan bans, ler actuel est une manœuvre destinée probablement à enoourager les baissiers à s'engager davantage, mais qne le "corner" sor Mai et Juillet existe réellement et que os qui est différé n’est pas perdn. On verra par la suite. En attendant les cours out fini par retourner à leur point de départ de la semaine.
Le samps est un peu meilleur en Amériqae et les ensemenoements procèdent plus régulièrement ; il y a toutefois du retard et c’est là un fait qui n’est pas à perdre de vne, quoique, au fond, le temps puisse tout arranger plus tard.
Chez none, comme nous l’avons déjà'dit. il y a du retard dans la Hante Egypte et ponr ce qui oonoerne la Basse-Bgypte, la température n’a pas été jucqu’ioi tout à frit favorable pour les eneemenoements de la nouvelle réoolte. Mais, pour ce qni est de la question de l'ean, les perspectives tout favorables, les avis du Soudan ayant encouragé les Travaux Publios à permettre l'augmentation de la ooltnro dn riz et à renvoyer an 15 Mai l’applioation des rotations qui avait été primitivement fixée au 1er Avril, tout' en réduisant le nombre des jours de chûmsge.
Graines de Coton.
Les arrivages ont été très petits et la eonré quence de la demande existante a produit de la hausse sur le disponible qui est à 69 1/4.
Le réveil de la demande anglaise que l’on voudrait ne c’est pas enoore fait sen'ir, mais il y a quand même un certain reienx dans l’air, un mieux qui pourrait s’aooentner aveo les l elites expédition qui ont lien et aveo la disparition, désormais complète, du disponible à Hull qui pesait tellement sor la situation. Les huiles étant aussi plus fermes, on peut toujours espérer. La dernière cote dn grand marché anglais it de £6.10/ –
En contrats, il n’y a que fort pen d'affaires, mais les cours n’ont fait qn’avancer et restent fermes à P.T. 70 1/4 poor l’Avril. De très grandes quantités ont été reportées sur les mois les pins éloignés, oe qui indiquerait que les détecteurs de contrats ne sont pas enoore disposés à liquider. Sur la nouvelle récolte il ne se traite absolument rien et la cote des 8 mois Novembre- Janvier reste nominale entre 61 1/2 et 62.

div.head: CHRONIQUE FINANCIERE
div.p:
Alexandrie, le 30 Mars. Ainsi que noos l’avions préva dans notie dernière obronique, notre marobé a subi uns réaotion, dne en paitie à la hausse exretsive de osrtsioes valeurs et aox difficultés de la liquidation de Mars, en partie à la suspension des séanoes d'Algéairas. Toute la oote a dono fléobi, et les premières valeurs qui ont profité de 1 amélioration des nouvelles sont précisément oelles que noua avions recommandées, à savoir 1e National Bank, l’Agrioole, la Delta Light et l’Investment. Le mérite d’one pareille prévision meilleures et qui ont été remplèb ment négligée» dorant des mois sont les mieox placées pour résister à une baisse et profiter d’une hausse.
Cette haussa est d'ailleore imminente. La spéculation, après s’être engouée outre mesure de valeurs nouvelles et les avoir poussées à des prix que rien ne justifie, oommenoe déjà à ressaisir et à se tourner vers les titres plus Zi*- rieox qu'elle a inconsidérément délaissés. Crt derniers profiteront d'sutant plus de la repiise qu’ils sont restés jusqu’à présent dépréoiée au profit d’autres qui ne jouissent pas des mêmes garanties et que oe revirement de l'attention publique se produit su moment même on l’argent regorge en Burope et où la oonféranoe do Maroo touoha à ta fin ; fin heureuse que noos n'avons oeesé d'affirmer, on nom rendra oette justire.
Malgré les dernières nouvelles optimistes tes marchés européens oontinnent à se tenir sur la réserve : le conaolidé anglais te relève bien de 90 J à 90 6/8, tandis que le taax privé d’es oompte baisse de 3 l/ à 8 8/8, mais U rente française fléchit de 99.80 à 99.06. On voit par là qne la bonne attend, pour se lanoer, 1a terminaison définitive de la oonféranoe.
loi U semaine a été à peu près nulle oomme affaires : Le début de samedi a été Üàible et baissier ; oette situation n’a fait qu’empirer jutqn’n mercredi, date à laquelle une reprise a en tien sur les valeurs solidw,Natioual Bank, Agrioole et Delia Light.—Cette nouvelle orientation du marobé s’est affirmée hier et aujourd'hui à 1» suite des aépéches optimistes d’Algésira». Il va sans dire, toutefois, qu’un mouvement tranché ne peut avoir lieu chet nous avant qne les marchés de Londres et de Paris nous donnent l’exemple.
Sur nn total de 48 valeurs inscrites h la oote officielle, 19 sont en hausse, 14 en baisse et 16 restent stationnaires. Les fl lOtuatious lea plus sensibles sunt : à la hausse, l’Agrioole qui gague 1/8, les Nuugovioh I 7/8, la Nils Laud 7/16,1» Laud Investment 1/4 et l’Urbaine 9/32 ; à 1» baisse, la Deferred Delta qni perd 1/4, la Khédivial Mail 9/6, et la part de fondateur Comptoir 2 livrée.
L’Bgyptian Investment and Agenoy, dépri- oiée ju.qae dernièrement, donne lieu depuis quelques jours à une forte demande et le ooute s’élève de oj chef à 1 7/16 aoheteure. Lee pourparlers oonoernant la oréation en Bgypie d’ane banque oommeroiale sont, partitif, en bonne vota
Par oontre, la Corporation of Western Egypt et la Land Allotment sont délaissées à des prix avantageux, oar les perspectives d’avenir de oes deux sooiété» sont des plus brillantes.
L'Assemblée générale ordinaire de la National Bank of Egypt a été tenue en Caire le 24 courant. Lea oomptee de l’exeroioe 1906 ont été approuvé] et il a été déoidé de distribuer uu dividende de 16 ahellinge par action, soit 8% sur le oapitaL L'assemblée extraordinaire qui devait enivre n'a pu avoir lieu, faute dn quorum requis par les statuts et a été renvoyée de oe chef an 16 avril proohain.
Ia Sooiété Prigonfiqned’Bgyptc avait déoidé la veille dans son assemblée générale de payer en dividende de P.T. 20 pour l’exercioe 1905.
Voioi la répartition des bénéficies, telle qo’elle sera proposée par le oonseil d'adminis- atration à l’assemblée générale de l’Egyptian Estates Co. qui doit se réunir à Londres le 11 Avril proohain : après le paiement de tous les frais préliminaires, ainsi qap de l’intérêt des obligations et la mise de £102,000 à la réserve, il sera distribué aux notions 2 shellings, oe qui pour un semestre représente du 20% anr le oapital versé, et IQ shellings 9 penoe aux parte de fondateurs ; les £9,200 qui restent seront reportées à nouveau.
Tout réoemment l’Bgyptian Estâtes Co. a vendu à la Bnilding Lande Co. un lot de terrain de 10.300 pire oarréa ponr la somme de 86 000 L.E. Ce terrain, situé en faoe du Collège des Jésuites d’Alexandrie, faisait partie de* propriétés aohetées par les Estâtes à M. 0. B. Alderson.
Le Banco di Borna a déoidé de porter son oapital de 80 à 40 millions de lranos par une nonvelle émission d'aotions, réservée aux
ac ion-.airos aotuels.
A l’assemblée des Entreprises Urbaines et Rurales tenue ici le 20 oonrant U a été déoidé de distribuer pour les 7 mois et demi de l’exer- oice 1905 P,T. 22 aux notions et P.T. 49.8 aux parte de fondateurs. Un» somme de L.B. 1077 eat reportée à nouveau.
Les reoettes de la Delta Light pour la dernière semaine se maintiennent dans les! mêmes proportions que précédemment, soit près de 10 % d’augmentation pour le résean du Delta et de 40 % sur la ligne de Hélouan.
Pour la Bamleh Hallway cette augmentatio' est encore plos sensible. Les leoettes pour la semaine finissant le 24 mars s’élèvent à 959 L E contre 699 L.E. l’année demiè-e.
Lundi prochain aura lieu au Caire l’assem blée des actionnaires de la Booiété Pondère d’Egypte tant anx effets spécifiés h l'artiole 8 des statuts relativement aux assemblées ord - nains que pour délibérer sur le proposition d’un versement à faire aox actionnaire*, an moyen d’une partie des bénéfices ét h imputer sur las £ 16, dont chique action est actuellement libérée. A psrtir dn 1er April prochain les coupon, de la Sooiété Anonyme des Baux du Caire pour l’exercioe 1905 seront payés aa Caire au
Ottomane : £20,193 aux actions de oapital, £20,819 aux notions de jouissanoest£l.950 aux parts de fondateurs.
La New Egyptian Co a conditionnellement alloué à ses actionnaires, dm, U proportion des titres qn’ils détiennent, 146,940 actions non voiles de au prix de 30 shelliogt sur la d’auMmUon nouvelle pour deux ancien- no-A Les laments seront effeetnée de le ma- èreWÿente : 6 shellings à l’aooeptation, 6 le 94 avril prochain et le solde en 4 ts égaux à intervalles de 8 mois an

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

Pills for the Liver & Kidneys
div.p: are an unfailing and reliable remedy for diseases of these important organs, gout, rheumatism, gravel pains in the back and kindred ailments (acquired or constitutional). Sold by principal Chemists, not in loose quantities, but only in boxes, price 2s. 3d bearing the British Government Stamp with the words "Eugene Le Clerc" impressed thereon to protect the public from fraud.

Medical, antiseptic, used and recommended by eminent dermatoligists in the treatment of ecsema, lepers, psoriasis, ulcerations, skin eruptions, itching and irritating skin humours, baby rashes, etc., also a prophylactic against the risk of contracting disease and infectionus disorders generally. div.head: CREDIT LYONNAIS
div.p: Société Anonyme
Capital 250,000,000 de francs
Entièrement Versés
Agences d'Égypte:
Alexandrie, Le Caire, Port-Said
Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.
